newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Datacraft in three-pronged growth strategy.
newsitem.headline: Datacraft in three-pronged growth strategy.

text.p: Telecommunications and network systems integrator Datacraft Asia Ltd said it would combine internal business growth, joint ventures and acquisitions to keep revenue and profits rising at double-digit rates.

"With a balanced growth strategy of organic growth, joint ventures and acquisitions, we expect to grow at a 40 percent rate," for 1997/1998, Des Althorp, the group's chief executive officer and managing director told a news briefing on Monday.
Datacraft projects both revenue and profit before tax would grow by about 40 percent for the year ending June 30, 1998, higher than the 35 percent it previously forecast.

For the year ended June 30, 1997, Datacraft's net profit jumped 54.8 percent to US$10.34 million on turnover of US$143.3 million, above analysts' consensus net profit forecast of S$14.2 million (US$9.4 million).
Althorp said the company was likely to form joint ventures to enter the Korean and Japanese markets and looking at opportunities in Vietnam.
Datacraft's core business segments are providing network equipment and infrastructure to telecoms service providers and large corporations, and services and support.
"The disappearing (telecommunications) monopoly gives us lots of opportunities to service new licences," Althorp said.
Datacraft was looking at new access network technology that would enable higher-speed inputs from operators, Althorp said.
Services were Datacraft's fasted growing area and a high margin business, which contributed 25 percent of pretax profit and 19 percent of revenue, he said.
Datacraft was aiming at services contributing 20 percent of revenue and 40 percent each from network business from telecoms service providers and corporations in three years' time.
Datacraft was looking to acquire more small to medium-sized companies with revenues of US$10-15 million as "an insurance against any unforeseen circumstances," Althorp said.
Such acquisitions would help it grow market share and acquire skills, he said.
On the currency turmoil in Asia, Althorp said most of the group's contracts were in U.S. currency and it was trying to make major contracts U.S.-dollar-based.
"We also have now currency fluctuation clauses in our contracts," he said, adding that prices would be increased if a currency moved more than five percent.

He said Thailand was a challenging market for Datacraft because customers had budget constraints and the economy was facing financial problems. But he still expected business in Thailand to grow this fiscal year.
Datacraft would also be raising capital to fund previous acquisitions and for working capital by the end of this year, Althorp said.
Ron Cattell, Datacraft's executive director, told Reuters the company was looking at raising US$30-50 million.
